stories.text:
I just found out that Maker Faire died. I never went to one, though now I wish I had.

What’s the equivalent now? Is maker culture dead or has it just fragmented? Do Adafruit or other organizations do conventions?

I realize nothing is stopping me from getting started on my own, but I like the idea of participating in a community
stories.title: Ask HN: How to get involved in “maker culture” these days?

stories.text:
As the title says, could someone lay out what would it look infrastructure/architecture wise to create one of those services?

I spend most of my time creating CRUD apps but I'm finding out I want to learn more of how the web really works.

For example, I know that for Heroku there are Open Source projects like CapRover [1] that fulfill similar needs. Would it be good to study the code of that project to understand how it works?

What technologies should I study? I'm thinking I should learn: * Docker * Nginx * AWS (S3, EC2, API Gateway, ...any other?)

Thanks in advance!! [1]: https://github.com/caprover/caprover
stories.title: Ask HN: How does one create a service like Vercel or Heroku?

stories.text: I need a simple service to send push notifications programmatically to my own phone. I don't want to make an entire app, but I am okay with (and know it will likely involve) downloading one. I don't want to use email or SMS. I want something like PagerDuty, but for myself. I want to send an API request and have my phone alert me the next second. Is there such a service?
stories.title: Ask HN: Good tool to send personal notifications?
A Brief Intro to Monad Transformers
